body: If all test pods were excluded with the filter, I'd kinda expect `helm test` to fail with "no pod logs for frame-poc-test". Your intent was to fetch the logs from the test, but they were all filtered out... What behaviour were you expecting?
I expected that helm would exit with 0 at least and may be with text like "no tests found" or something like that.

It's worse than that: if _any_ test Pod is excluded by a filter, you get that error message.

The code that attempts to fetch the logs ignores the filters. https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/9bf3a14203099759713828aae8b880776e8ff261/pkg/action/release_testing.go#L104

Making it effectively impossible to use --filter with --logs.
Yes. Please feel free to contribute a patch.

I came here looking for a solution why our tests "randomly" (= we don't know why) fail when we use them with "--logs and --filter". Maybe your PR would have helped. I hope it gets accepted soon.

We have the same issue and would really appreciate if this is fixed. 

We want to run a specific helm test suite and then fetch the logs of the test pod on client side. Unfortunately, we cannot use "--logs and --filter" flags together for that. The error even prevents retrieving the logs of the pods which are not excluded by the filter.

I hope this PR gets merged soon. This seems like a very basic feature that is missing. The logs output should simply contain the logs from the test pods that were deployed with the command that was run.

Because this doesn't work, not only do we get the error about logs not found, but also logs from actual tests that were run are not displayed. This makes the --logs flag completely unusable with --filter which is crucial for a large test suite.

issue.title: Helm test --logs to optionally output only from failed tests
issue.body:
It would be great if aside from [respecting --filter when using the --logs flag](https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/10566) we were also able to specify that `helm test --logs` outputs only logs from failed tests.

An example use-case is for CI/CD pipelines, so that logs are output only if there is an error, for investigation, whereas successful tests simply yield some short success message and exit.

This is especially useful for cases where we want to delete the test pod after execution so as to not take up space on the cluster, especially since investigating test failures can take place a while after the test execution. Furthermore, looking at test job results is faster and more convenient than searching through Pod logs.

### Suggested solution 1 - an additional 'logs-failed' flag

`helm test mychart --logs-failed`

### Suggested solution 2 - parameters for the existing 'logs' flag

`helm test mychart --logs all` (default)
`helm test mychart --logs failed`
`helm test mychart --logs succeeded`
